title: Metrics for Zone 2 Training
content: Metrics for finding Zone 2 threshold include lactate, heart rate, and more. In a patient or a world class athlete, indirect calorimetry and lactate testing can be used to determine Zone 2 training. The lactate measured in the blood is heavily influenced by production and clearance. The gold standard would be to measure fat oxidation, but this can be confounded in people on a ketogenic diet.

title: Zone 2 Test Based on Fat Oxidation
content: With patients, a Zone 2 test can be done based on their fat oxidation during an escalated VO2 max test. For example, their maximum fat oxidation may be 0.3 g/min, and this occurs at a wattage of 1.5 watts/kg.

title: Training to Achieve Zone 2
content: Patients won’t be able to train with indirect calorimetry. Some people will have lactate meters and some people won’t. In this example, the patient oxidizes the most fat at a workload of 1.5 watts/kg. The goal is to increase this to 2.5.

title: Recommendations for Zone 2 Training
content: Training can start with a metabolic test; this information can provide watts, or speed, or heart rate. Another metric used is RPE, or rating of perceived exertion. From experience, being in Zone 2 is when lactate levels are between 1.7-1.9 mmol. Exercising at a level where you can carry on a conversation and it feels a bit strained is a good surrogate for knowing you’re in Zone 2.
